topics.title: Mindset shift: reframing “pushback” at work
topics.summary: Jason explains why the word “pushback” primes negativity and argues for reframing disagreement as aligning on goals and helping the business succeed. He introduces the idea that effective disagreement starts by understanding the other person’s underlying objective.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces the podcast, Jason as the guest, and previews topics (Web3 PMing, leadership, hiring, pushing back, career growth). Jason then gives a concise career overview from founding a teen startup through Yammer/Microsoft, do.com/Amazon, Airbnb, and Alchemy in Web3.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Coda and Amplitude, including a short conversation with John Cutler about Amplitude’s expansion into experimentation and CDP to support the full product loop.

topics.title: Why they re-recorded: Web3 changed fast
topics.summary: Lenny explains they previously recorded an episode focused on Web3, but the market shifted and it felt stale, so they’re redoing it. Jason reacts and they set up the conversation to revisit Web3 with fresh context.

topics.title: State of Web3 during crypto winter
topics.summary: Jason argues Web3 is stronger than ever despite price drops, citing growing company formation, early PMF, record activity, and scaling tech (L2s, new launches). He frames volatility as normal for new technologies, amplified by early financialization.

topics.title: Leading through downturns: morale via progress
topics.summary: Jason shares how to keep teams focused during Web3 cycles: morale comes from visible progress, shipping, and customer/developer traction—not speeches or extrinsic incentives. He draws parallels to Airbnb’s COVID revenue collapse and the importance of hiring mission-driven builders.

topics.title: PMs in Web3: from optional to essential
topics.summary: Jason updates his earlier view that Web3 needs fewer PMs, noting a clear shift toward hiring PMs and product leaders as products mature and competition increases. They discuss how great PMs become a competitive advantage and why skepticism often comes from lack of exposure to strong PM craft.

topics.title: What surprised Jason most about Web3 products
topics.summary: Jason is surprised by how far Web3 products have scaled without traditional PM roles or playbooks, citing examples like Uniswap’s scale relative to Coinbase and NFT communities building ambitious experiences. He contrasts lean teams and unconventional structures with Web2 norms.

topics.title: Which company shaped his product approach most
topics.summary: Jason says Amazon most influenced his product thinking because it tightly couples product decisions with business outcomes (revenue, GTM, ownership). He notes learning impact can be non-linear with tenure and shares how company “stage” proxies can mislead versus actual culture.

topics.title: Amazon’s “working backwards” and writing discipline
topics.summary: Jason explains the PRFAQ working-backwards process and how Amazon’s writing standards (specificity, numbers over adjectives, concision) force clarity and de-risk decisions. He outlines the PR structure (announcement, problem, solution, customer quote, leadership quote, CTA) and how it differs from Airbnb’s 11-star ideal.

topics.title: Traits of great leaders: humility, details, adaptability
topics.summary: Jason distills leadership lessons from leaders like David Sacks, Bezos, and Chesky: nothing is beneath them, they operate in the details to uphold craft and accountability, and they adapt quickly to new information. Lenny adds examples of founder-level design and launch reviews driving quality.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Maven, highlighting cohort-based courses taught by experienced operators and listing example instructors and topics.

topics.title: Ownership culture: responsibility beats accountability
topics.summary: They discuss how quality degrades when no one feels deep ownership, and Jason contrasts top-down accountability systems with fostering responsibility and pride. He gives examples from Airbnb and Alchemy of people stepping up beyond role boundaries.

topics.title: How to “push back” on CEOs: align on goals
topics.summary: Jason reframes pushback as direction-shifting through shared goals rather than saying no, then illustrates with an Airbnb Luxury Retreats integration example where redefining the experience (concierge → trip designer) reduced scope while improving customer value. They discuss why effective reframing requires both a bigger idea and clear communication, not just renaming.
